ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic Modern Greek! Firm grounding in present tense over several verb groups, began some subjunctive and irregular verb forms. Lots of vocabulary on things to do in your free time, travel, greetings, basic convo, prepositions, places around town, etc. I can hold a basic conversation in Greek and write letters too!
I feel like I have a solid grasp on introductory Greek.
Good start to learning to read, write, speak, and understand Greek.
I learned the fundamentals of speaking the Greek language including, characters, pronunciation, reading and writing words, sentence structure, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Maria is an incredible teacher and was DEFINITELY the biggest strength of the course. She always had a good lesson plan and activities for us to do which consistently kept the class engaged and interested. 
Weaknesses: I feel like a lot of people will say this and I do agree a bit: the book doesn't include vocab lists or anything in English. In some ways, this is actually a pretty helpful way to teach foreign language. For me, I learned very well with it. But I can see for others who prefer the lists and direct translations that this could be a potential weakness.

The Prof does not overwhelm students with vocabulary and incorporates learning how to speak and read the language into the curriculum too. The only downside is that the textbook does not have any English in it (but in class we define all the vocab words anyway so it's not a terrible issue).
Strengths: Teacher is fantastic, material is not overwhelming, high retention rate of content covered. Weaknesses: the textbook is somewhat confusing and hard to understand at times

Strengths are the pacing, the level of interaction and engagement during class, and the flexibility of the instructor in adapting lesson plans to how students are learning the material. 

One thing that could be improved is assigning more homework, to ensure students get more reading and writing experience on their own.
Biggest strength is the professor! She is so extremely kind, warm, patient, and fun. It's a real joy to walk into class and see her everyday.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: ABSOLUTELY! If you're looking for a fun new language to try, please please please take Greek!!! It's a 9:25am class but I never once dreaded coming to learn in the morning. Maria will make it worth your time, and you learn so much! The workload is also not insane like some other language courses, and I feel it teaches just as much.
Yes! I've always disliked language classes but this class is taught in such a way where students actually learn the language and internalize it.
Yes absolutely - this is the only language class I've ever taken that I have thoroughly enjoyed
Yes, definitely recommend to anyone interested in Modern Greek or just learning a new language.
Yes! If you're looking for a cool, niche language that'll stimulate you and set you apart from your peers, Modern Greek is for you!
